content: --स्थः [ककुदि तिष्ठतीति] an epithet of Puraṃjaya, son of Śaśāda, a king of the solar race, and a descendant of Ikṣvāku; इक्ष्वाकुवंश्यः ककुदं नृपाणां ककुत्स्थ इत्याहितलक्षणोऽभूत् <ls>R. 6. 71.</ls> [Mythology relates that, when in their war with the demons, the gods were often worsted, they, headed by Indra, went to the powerful king Puraṃjaya, and requested him to be their friend in battle. The latter consented to do so, provided Indra carried him on his shoulders. Indra accordingly assumed the form of a bull, and Puraṃjaya, seated on its hump, completely vanquished the demons. Puraṃjaya is, therefore, called {%Kakutstha%} ‘standing on a hump’].
